front.note: 0 1989 by The American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Inc.

docTitle.titlePart:
Purification and Characterization of an a-1,Z-Mannosidase Involved in
Processing Asparagine-linked Oligosaccharides*

byline.docAuthor: W. Thomas Forsee, Christopher F. Palmer, and John S. Schutzbach

byline.affiliation: From the Department of Microbiology, University of Alabama,

front.div:
A calcium-dependent a-1,Z-mannosidase involved in
the processing of asparagine-linked oligosaccharides
was purified to homogeneity from rabbit liver micro-
somes. N-terminal amino acid analysis was consistent
with the presence of a homogeneous protein. Sodium
dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis,
under both reducing and nonreducing conditions, re-
vealed a single protein band with an apparent molec-
ular weight of 52,000. Gel filtration and sedimentation
analysis under nondenaturing
conditions suggested
that the purified enzyme is a monomeric protein. The
mannosidase is a glycoprotein based on the presence of
protein-linked sugar and specific binding of the en-
zyme to concanavalin A-Sepharose. Purified mannos-
idase was optimally active between pH 6.0 and 6.0.
The enzyme was inactive withp-nitrophenyl-a-D-man-
nopyranoside and was inhibited by deoxymannojiri-
mycin but not by swainsonine. The enzyme was specif-
ically activated by Ca", with half-maximal activation
occurring at concentrations of 10 pM or less and was
inhibited by Mn2+, Co2+, Ba2+, and Zn2+. Calcium ions
protected the enzyme against inactivation by p-chlo-
romercuribenzoate. Rabbit liver mannosidase hydro-
lyzed a-1,Z-mannosyl-mannose linkages in a variety
of substrates including methyl-2-O-a-D-mannopy-
ranosyl-a-D-mannopyranoside (Schutzbach, J. S.
(1987) Anal. Biochem. 167,279-283), ovalbumin gly-
copeptide IV, and the high mannose chains of thyro-
globulin and phytohemagglutinin-P. Approximately
70% of the a-l,Z-linked mannosyl units in the oligo-
saccharides of thyroglobulin were accessible to rabbit
liver a-mannosidase, whereas most of the a-1,Z-man-
nosy1 units in phytohemagglutinin were resistant to
digestion prior to heat denaturation of the plant lectin.
